titleStmt.title: Headnote to The Tragedy of Charles the First
titleStmt.author: Rebecca Nesvet

sponsor.orgName: Mary Russell Mitford Society: Digital Mitford Project

seriesStmt.title: Digital Mitford: The Mary Russell Mitford Archive

body.p: In spite of the unfortunate event of my late effort Charles the First, I still wish to make another attempt at Historical Tragedy, wrote Mary Russell Mitford on 18 December 1825. She addressed this missive to George Colman, the London theatre playwright, manager, and advisor to the Licenser of Plays. Mitford planned to dramatize the conflict between the medieval Archbishop Thomas of Becket and King Henry II, who apparently arranged Becket's assassination. Before writing this work, Mitford wished to know if Colman would approve of its presentation. Your opinion, or rather your advice, whether for or against the play is all I ask, she assured him. She would be equally grateful for his approval of the idea or his kind warning to desist. Mitford 413

Mitford had reason to worry that Colman might find her attempt at Historical Tragedy objectionable, and even unproduceable. A few weeks earlier, he had advised the Licenser, Lord Montrose, to reject Mitford’s completed Tragedy of Charles the First. On 29 September 1825, Colman informed Montrose that Mitford's title brings, instantly, to mind the violent commotions of the Caroline era, and, more dangerously exhibits the fanatical manners (mores) and puritanical cant of Oliver Cromwell and his associates. Also, she blasphemously employs Scriptural allusions, & quotations, and characters take the name of the Lord in vain Colman 408. Montrose concluded that the play is certainly not proper for representationGraham 410 in a theatre. On 10 October, Colman duly suspended the play's license on account of its peculiar title & incidents Colman to Mitford, 409. In these two men's shared view, Mitford’s depiction of the events leading up to the Regicide could not be produced for public audiences.

That Mitford did not check with Colman before writing this play reinforces the impression that Montrose’s decision blindsided her. Perhaps it should not have. On Saturday, 26 January 1649, Charles Stuart, formerly known as King Charles I, was tried for High Treason, convicted, and sentenced to death. The sentence was carried out four days later, on a scaffold erected in front of the ornate Banqueting-House that had been designed for his father by Inigo Jones. Jones had also been a designer of stage sets, so the execution of the once-royal prisoner, who approached wearing densely bejewelled gloves, might have seemed particularly theatrical. But a generation later, in 1660, the English monarchy was restored, under Charles's son Charles II. In that year, the Act of Indemnity and Oblivion criminalized any discussion of the Regicide that might serve to revive the memory of the late differences, or to investigate any surviving Briton’s involvement in Charles’s deposition and death Norbrook 1.

This Act suppressed Commonwealth history well into the eighteenth century. For instance, the late-eighteenth-century descendants of one Regicide, Colonel John Hutchinson, embargoed his wife Lucy Hutchinson’s manuscript account of her husband’s exploits, her own political activity, and her hopes for a future in which their religious and political ideals would not be condemned. When the historian and Republican Virago Catharine Macaulay (1731-1791) implored the Hutchinson descendant Sir Thomas Hutchinson to publish the memoir, he refused See Hutchinson, J., ed., 'Preface'. It first appeared, with a profusion of Whiggish apology from Sir Thomas's nephew Julius Hutchinson, in 1806.

Despite the horror that the Regicide evoked during the Restoration, early in the eighteenth century it was the subject of a stage tragedy in which it carried a politically mainstream meaning. As Colman and Montrose knew, in 1737, the playwright William Havard had seen his King Charles the First, An Historical Tragedy produced at Drury Lane. In 1737, Charles I was generally associated not with tyrannical monarchy, but with treason against the new Hanoverian dynasty, because his brother's descendants and self-proclaimed heirs, the Old Pretender James Francis Stuart and Young Pretender, Charles Edward Stuart (also known as "Bonnie Prince Charlie") threatened Britain with invasion. This threat the Stuart faction carried out twice, in 1715 and 1719, and would attempt for a final time in 1745. In this context, Stuart typically meant traitor. The late eighteenth-century evaporation of the Jacobite threat, observes critic Richard McCoy, made Havard's Charles a figure of pathos and pity McCoy 135. Thus abjectly humanized, the doomed king did not invite parallel with George II.

By the Regency, the meaning of the Regicide had again changed. The massive unpopularity of the mad king George III (d. 1820) and his successor George IV invalidated Havard's safeguards. One copy of the 1806 edition of Lucy Hutchinson's memoir, now in the collection of the University of California at Los Angeles, testifies to this change. In this copy, anonymous manuscript annotations likely written between 1806 and 1811Date of annotations estimated based on textual references to the future George IV, Prince Regent from 1811 to 1820, as the Prince of Wales. communicate horrified premonitions. The annotator sees horrid omens in the play's dedication to the Prince of Wales: omens, perhaps, that he would die by legislative fiat, as did Louis XVI of France in 1793. And then: The fanaticism of the writer [Lucy Hutchinson], & the Jacobinism of the Editor [Julius Hutchinson], render a steady perusal impossible. Yet it is dedicated with permission to the Prince of Wales! O horrible most horrible! See UCLA copy containing the notes of the anonymous annotator, which may be accessed at Internet Archive: Later in the Regency, Sir Walter Scott created a new narrative of the defunct Jacobite struggle. In this narrative, George IV inherited the Stuart claim to the British throne and even earned a dubious Scottish cultural identity by dint of his distant Scottish ancestry and the apparent will of the people of Edinburgh, through a royal visit that had been carefully stage-managed by Scott McCracken-Flesher 109.

Meanwhile, voices of reform began to put the suppressed memory of the Regicides to new and radical use. In 1819, Percy Bysshe Shelley began writing another tragedy based on Charles the First. As Nora Crook demonstrates, this radical political drama deprecates both Charles and Cromwell, and explores the utopian potential of the Commonwealth envisioned by the complicated rebel and republican martyr Sir Henry Vane. Why Shelley abandoned this play is unclear, but he wrote in frustration of his sympathy for Charles, suggesting that his envisioned Regicidal drama was self-censored Crook, "Calumniated Republicans" 163-165; see also Crook, "Shelley's Late" 300-301.

While Shelley’s Charles the First fulfilled a political exigency, Mitford was drawn by the subject’s potential as a vehicle for the actor-manager William Macready. To Mitford, Cromwell was one of the most remarkable creatures that ever figured in the great Theatre of LifeSee Mitford's 1834 Preface to Charles I. Modern historians agree: as Alan Marshall contends, few men in the past have attracted more enthusiasts and detractorsMarshall 7. Macready tended to play rebels and despots, including Richard III; the pseudohistorical Swiss revolutionary William Tell; Lord Byron's doomed Oriental tyrant Sardanapalus; and the Cardinal Richelieu, the posthumously infamous architect of Louis XIV's France, who is now perhaps best known as the villain in The Three Musketeers.

At the same time, Mitford's Charles the First is not apolitical. Diego Saglia has demonstrated that many plays produced in the London patent theatres during the 1820s opening of the Age of Reform investigate the concept of liberty, and Mitford’s are no exception. As Saglia points out, her Rienzi, inspired by the medieval Italian rebel (or demagogue) Cola di Rienzo, fits this description. So does Charles the First, whose characters attempt to balance different sorts of liberties—domestic as well as political and spiritual , 'The Talking Demon' 363. In this play, Cromwell claims to represent the people of England, but privately nurses tyrannic ambition. Mitford indicates this hypocrisy early in the drama, by giving Cromwell conspiratorial asides reminiscent of those of Shakespeare's (and Macready's) Richard III. For example, while Cromwell allows his New Model Army comrades to brainstorm ways to deal with the deposed king, and one, Major-General Sir Thomas Harrison suggests exiling him like the Biblical king Amaziah, Cromwell remarks (Aside) Ha! And they slew him [Amaziah]! Thus Cromwell diabolically deciphers Harrison's unspoken wish, then engineers its dread fulfillment as a communal act. And yet, he also persuasively champions political liberty. He warns the would-be Regicides that should Charles survive, he will avenge himself. Then:

quote.l: The liberty for which the blood of saints
And martyrs hath been spilt, freedom of act,
Of speech, of will, of faith!

body.p: Surely this is a paean to liberty, no matter its motivation.

Mitford's representation of Charles seems equally diplomatic. Charles’s complicating humanity apparently catalyzed Shelley’s internal censor, but Mitford embraces psychological and moral complexity, making Charles at once a loving father, an impassioned husband, and a disastrous king. Henrietta Maria, Charles's French queen, displays similar depth--and frequently steals the scene. Anachronistically styling herself a Gothic heroine, Henrietta Maria stalks castle corridors in search of her imprisoned love, rails at his enemies, and, when she finds him, offers to trade her life for his via a ruse that strongly anticipates Sydney Carton’s redemptive self-sacrifice in A Tale of Two Cities, which Charles Dickens would not write until four years after Mitford’s death.

When Mitford's rich dramatic tapestry failed to impress Colman and Montrose, Mitford revised it, and it was finally staged and published in 1834. By then, the climate had become more favorable. In a new preface, Mitford claims that although her work was never revolutionary, [...] against such a king as William IV, rebellion's shafts would fall harmless. (How they might have struck George IV in 1825, she does not speculate.)

Still, the unfortunate event that linked Mitford's play with English Republican transgression may have kept haunting her. In 1840, the struggle for various kinds of reform, including working-class male suffrage, had culminated with the composition of the People’s Charter and its presentation to Parliament. Its suspected primary author, William Lovett, was serving a three-year sentence at Warwick Gaol for having allegedly incited Chartist demonstrators at Birmingham’s Bull Ring to violence. Mitford was writing on commission again, this time for the ornate illustrated compendium Finden’s Tableaux. The Roundhead’s Daughter makes it clear where her sympathies lie with regards to the English Civil War, the Commonwealth, and the Regicide. In this story, Mitford’s Parliamentarians are Puritans, and are stereotypically Puritanical. The heroine, Mabel Goodwin, wears the pinched coif and demure kerchief of the Puritans, squandering her beauty 36. Also squandered by the Commonwealth-men are England’s land and cultural heritage. In 1658, the English countryside is characterized by neglected desolation, and the heroine’s suitor’s father, the disenfranchised Cavalier Lord Philip Montresor, has seen his magnificent mansion, where the Virgin Queen once danced with his ancestor, stolen by the Committee of Sequestration and bestowed upon Mabel’s father, Colonel Goodwin, a plain soldier and zealous Roundhead36. Luckily, Mabel defies her father and Cromwell’s regime to marry her nobleman, and, after the Restoration, Lord Philip magnanimously saves the Colonel and facilitates the reconciliation in tranquillity of the formerly warring factions. Like the ending of Waverley, that of The Roundhead’s Daughter preaches reconciliation in a context favorable to the Hanoverian victors. Also uniting morality (Good win[s]) with wealth (Montresor means my treasure), Mitford lets her audience know that in the Victorian era, the dissensions of the Civil War have been completely healed.

Only that was perhaps an optimistic view. Even in the twentieth century, physically simulating the corporeal reality of the Regicide on the mainstream London stage remains taboo. In the 2012 Hampstead Theatre, London premiere of Howard Brenton’s play 55 Days, the executioner lifts his axe above the deposed king, but before the blade can fall, the curtain does. The continuing controversiality of this execution as stage drama compels us to reread Mitford's take—and perhaps to revive it.

org.note: Members of the Chartist movement working for political reform in Great Britain between 1838 and 1857. The movement and its supporters took their name from the People's Charter (1838), a statement of their political aims. The movement aimed to achieve six reforms, largely through constitutional methods, including the presentation of petitions to the House of Commons signed by millions of citizens. The reforms included: 1)universal manhood suffrage for those age 21 and above, eliminating the property ownership requirement for male voters, 2)vote by secret ballot, eliminating the publication of votes 3)elimination of the property requirement for Members of Parliament, 4)payment for service as a Member of Parliament, making office-holding financially feasible for those without independent incomes, 5)redrawing constituency boundaries to ensure that each M.P. represented the same number of voters, equalizing constituencies and eliminating so-called rotten boroughs, and 5)annual parliamentary elections, aimed at decreasing the practice of bribing or intimidating voters.
Supporters of Cromwell and the parliamentary cause in the English Civil War. Also called English Republicans or Roundheads.

Began in the 16th century as an anti-Catholic reform movement within the Church of England, some of whose members emigrated to the Netherlands, Ireland, and Scotland, and later to America. Puritans were not a single religious sect with a unified theological or political viewpoint. In the early 17th century, they allied themselves with Scottish Presbyterians and with English parliament members who opposed the royal perogative. They came to power after the first English Civil War and the majority of Puritan clergy left the Church of England after the Restoration to practice as nonconformists/dissenters.
Supporters of the Stuart cause. Named after the line of Jacob, that is, the descendants of James I.

person.note: As Archbishop of Canterbury, Becket quarreled with King Henry II over the balance of power between the church and crown. Becket was murdered by four knights while at prayer in Canterbury Cathedral. The king had reportedly been heard to ask the four knights "Will no one rid me of this meddlestome priest?," thereby calling for Becket's assassination without literally ordering it. Becket was canonized by the Roman Catholic Church as a saint in 1173.

Henry II, the son of Geoffrey Plantagenet and the Empress Matilda, was denominated the heir of Matilda's cousin King Stephen at the conclusion of the Wars of Stephen and Matilda. Ruler of an empire that stretched from France to Scotland, Henry is known for his marriage to Eleanor of Aquitaine, his quarrel with and apparent involvement in the assassination of Thomas of Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury (later St. Thomas of Canterbury), and the wars between his sons, which contributed to his death at the age of fifty-six. Source: Britannica.

death.placeName: Somerset House, the Strand, London, England

person.note: Educated in Italy, Inigo Jones attracted the patronage of the English and Scandinavian courts and developed the English Neoclassical style of architecture. His buildings include James I's Banqueting Hall at Whitehall Palace, London which, within Jones's lifetime, later served as the backdrop for the execution of Charles I.

person.persName: John Hutchinson Hutchinson John Colonel Sir Governor of Nottingham Castle Commissioner, High Court of Justice Member, Council of State Member of Parliament for Nottingham
person.note: A Cambridge-educated Parliamentarian leader of Puritan convictions during the English Civil Wars, Hutchinson subsequently participated in the trial of Charles I and signed his death warrant, thereby becoming a regicide. The husband and biographical subject of the writer Lady Lucy Hutchinson, Hutchinson escaped execution for regicide under suspicious circumstances apparently engineered by his wife. However, he was arrested in 1663 for allegedly plotting against King Charles II and died in prison. The extremely belated publication of Lucy Hutchinson's Memoirs of the Life of Colonel Hutchinson (1806) made him posthumously famous.

note.p: An exceptionally well-educated and self-assured early modern woman whose literary achievements are extremely significant. Her works include the first complete English translation of Lucretius's controversial Epicurean poem De Rerum Natura (in ms. only until 2012), the epic poem Order and Disorder, which has been read as a proto-feminist take on Genesis that invites comparison with her contemporary John Milton's Paradise Lost, and her Memoir of the Life of Colonel John Hutchinson, a biography of her husband that brings to life the drama of the Civil Wars and the idealism of the Puritans, particularly for religious liberty and republican government. This work, published in 1806, is the only Lucy Hutchinson composition that was known as such during Mitford's lifetime.

Born Lucy Apsley, the daughter of Sir Allen Apsley, Lieutenant of the Tower of London. In 1638 she fell mutually in love with and married Sir John Hutchinson. While he fought on the Parliamentarian side in the English Civil Wars, she provided material assistance, at one point contriving for her brother-in-law (Hutchinson's brother) to pose as him while the real Colonel Hutchinson escaped arrest by the Royalists. At the Restoration, she may have saved his life by forging an apologetic letter that he might have been more reticent to write.
As the critic Devoney Looser has shown, Lucy Hutchinson became an extremely well-known figure during the nineteenth century, featuring as a heroine in many works of fiction and drama.

person.note: Important English historian during the eighteenth century, celebrated and vilified during her lifetime as a female intellectual, "Bluestocking," and the "Republican Virago." Her politics were Whig, reformist, and anti-Catholic, and they became increasingly radical in her later years, when she attacked the writings of Edmund Burke. Whigs embraced the early volumes of her History of England as supporting their views of political history. Her interpretation of the English Civil War was influential; she wrote admiringly of the Parliamentarians and condemned both Oliver Cromwell and the execution of Charles I.

A lateral descendant of Sir John Hutchinson through his brother Charles (1637-1695), Sir Thomas Hutchinson had posession of the manuscript of Lucy Hutchinson's Memoirs of the Life of Sir John Hutchinson at Owthorpe in the eighteenth century, where historian Catherine Macaulay consulted it. During his lifetime, he refused to published the manuscript, which was later published by his newphew Julius.

A lateral descendant of Sir John Hutchinson through his brother Charles (1637-1695), Julius Hutchinson edited Lucy Hutchinson's Memoirs of the Life of Sir John Hutchinson from the manuscript at Owthorpe (the Hutchinson estate) and allowed it to be published in 1806.

birth.placeName: Palazzo Muti, Rome, States of the Church

death.placeName: Palazzo Muti, Rome, States of the Church

person.note: The famously beautiful son of the "Old Pretender" (James, son of the deposed King James II), Charles Edward Stuart (also known as "the Young Pretender" and "Bonnie Prince Charlie" staged an invasion of Scotland in 1745. The resulting Jacobite Wars resulted in Stuart's decisive defeat at the Battle of Culloden (1746) and his evacuation, in female disguise, to the Isle of Skye, and eventual Continental exile. His death ended the Jacobite attempts to recover the British crown.
Distinguished Professor of English at Queens College and the Graduate Center, CUNY.
UW George Duke Humphrey Distinguished Professor in the Department of English at the University of Wyoming.

persName.roleName: George the Second, by the Grace of God, King of Great Britain, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg, Archtreasurer and Prince-Elector of the Holy Roman Empire
King of Great Britain and Ireland

person.note: King of Great Britain and Ireland and Elector of Hanover from 1727, the eldest son of Hanoverian George I and second cousin once removed to Queen Anne. He was also a Knight of the Garter and was created Duke and Marquess of Cambridge, Earl of Milford Haven, Viscount Northallerton, and Baron Tewkesbury. Prior to becoming King, while Prince of Wales, he opposed his father's policies in concert with Whig politicians Robert Walpole and Charles Townshend. The War of the Austrian Succession, the Jacobite Rebellion, and the Seven Years' War took place during his reign. He is the most recent British monarch to be buried in Westminter Abbey.

persName.roleName: Fellow of the Royal Historical Society

person.note: Fellow of the Royal Historical Society, Head of Humanities, and a faculty member in the Department of History at Bath Spa University.

Became a cardinal of the Catholic Church in 1622 and served as Louis XIII's chief minister from 1624 until his death. He helped transform France into a centralized state under strong royal governance. He also guided French government during the Thirty Years' War and during the consolidation of France's role in the Americas. He has been depicted as a scheming, villainous character in popular fiction frequently, including an appearance in Alexandre Dumas's The Three Musketeers.

persName.roleName: His Most Christian Majesty The King of France

person.death: Place de la Révolution, Paris, France
person.note: Last King of France during the Ancien Régime, he ruled as absolute monarch until 1789 and after the French Revolution as a constitutional monarch until 1792. He was imprisoned, tried, and guillotined in 1792-1793.
English journalist and editor, novelist, and lecturer. Considered one of the most important novelists of the Victorian era.

After working as a ropemaker in Cornwall, Lovett sought better work in London. He joined various working-class political societies and became the leader of the London Working-Man's Association (LMDA), which played a major role in the Chartist movement. Lovett wrote the People's Charter, which was thrice unsuccessfully presented to Parliament, and also a memoir, The Life and Struggles of William Lovett in his Pursuit of Bread, Knowledge, and Freedom (1876).

persName.roleName: Fellow of the Royal Literary Society (FRLS)

person.note: Contemporary British playwright, most famous for the deeply controversial drama The Romans in Britain (1980), a historical allegory that critiqued the British occupation of Northern Ireland by paralleling it with the Roman Invasion and depicted rape in the context of war. He also wrote 55 Days (2012), a dramatization of the events between the New Model Army's conquest of London and the execution of Charles I. The original production, at London's Hampstead Theatre, starred the writer Mark Gatiss as Charles and Douglas Henshall as Oliver Cromwell. Modern costumes (in the original production) and language support this play's promotion of contemporary British consideration of a republican political reformation, a possibility later explored far more directly in Mike Bartlett's play King Charles III, which premiered at the Almeida Theatre in 2017.
Emeritus Merton Professor of Renaissance English literature at Oxford University.
Emeritus Professor of English Literature at Anglia Ruskin University in Cambridge and Chelmsford, formerly CCAT.
Title character from Shakespeare's The Life and Death of Richard III, loosely based on the historical King Richard III. One of William Macready's most prominent roles.
Title character from Knowles's play William Tell, loosely based on the pseudohistorical Swiss revolutionary; role created by and for William Macready.
Title character from Byron's tragedy Sardanapalus, about a doomed Assyrian tyrant. Role William Macready originated the role in 1834, after Byron's death.
Title character from Edward Bulwer-Lytton Richelieu, loosely based on the historical Cardinal Richelieu; role created by and for William Macready.
Protagonist in A Tale of Two Cities; he is a young, alcoholic London lawyer upon whose self-reformation and self-sacrifice during the Reign of Terror forms a hinge upon which the plot turns.
Title character in The Roundhead's Daughter.
Cavalier character in The Roundhead's Daughter.
Roundhead character in The Roundhead's Daughter; father of the title character.

place.note: Warwick Gaol was a functioning county jail located next to a town building that would later grow to be Shire Hall. The jail remained open until the late eighteenth century, when it was condemned by reformer John Howard.

Began in the twelfth century as a central market district for Birmingham. From the 1830s to the 1860s, also a popular location for public preaching and political protests. Location of the 1839 Chartist demonstration for voting reform in England, known as the Bull Ring Riots.

bibl.title: A Tale of Two Cities
The Three Musketeers
Les Trois Mousquetaires
bibl.author: Alexandre Dumas
bibl.note: First published in serial form in the French newspaper Le Siècle between March and July 1844; by 1846, it had been adapted and translated into English by more than one publisher.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Life of Colonel Hutchinson
bibl.note: Lady Lucy Hutchinson composed the Memoirs sometime between the date of her husband's death in 1664 and the year 1675, when she presented the manuscript to Arthur, Earl of Anglesey. It was published in 1806 under the direction of Rev. Julius Hutchinson, a Hutchinson descendant. Before then, the manuscript had been consulted at the Hutchinson family library at Owthorpe by the historian Catherine Macaulay and possibly by others.
UCLA copy contains the notes of an anonymous annotator and a digital copy may be accessed at Internet Archive:

bibl.title: People's Charter
bibl.note: The formal declaration of the Chartist movement, which the Chartists strove to have adopted by Parliament as British law. Three successful petitions pursuing this end failed to persuade Parliament.

bibl.title: The Roundhead's Daughter
Findens' Tableaux: The Iris of Prose, Poetry, and Art for MDCCXL [1840]
bibl.author: Mary Russell Mitford
bibl.note: A short story by Mary Russell Mitford set during the English Republican Era and the Restoration, in which the title character, Puritan Mabel Goodwin, falls in love with the Royalist Arthur Montresor, son of Sir Philip Montresor. Also collected in Finden's Tableaux of National Character, Beauty, and Costume, 2 : 160-165.

bibl.title: Findens' Tableaux: The Iris of Prose, Poetry, and Art for MDCCXL [1840]
bibl.note: 1840 annual edited by Mitford, to which she contributed six selections.

bibl.title: Finden's Tableaux of National Character, Beauty, and Costume
bibl.note: A two-volume anthology of previously-published stories and poems from Finden's Tableaux. Mitford's contributions to these volumes consist of twenty short stories and one long poem. Elizabeth Barrett was also one of the contributors. The issue is made up of two volumes, numbered consecutively. A plate accompanies each selection; however, plates are not numbered.

bibl.title: The Proud Ladye. A Chapter from the Chronicles of Adlersberg.
Findens' Tableaux: The Iris of Prose, Poetry, and Art for MDCCXL [1840]
bibl.author: Mary Russell Mitford
bibl.note: A short story by Mary Russell Mitford. Also collected in Finden's Tableaux of National Character, Beauty, and Costume, 2 : 104-108.

bibl.title: The Charles the First Draft Notebook: A Facsimile of Bodleian MS. Shelley adds. e. 17
bibl.author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
bibl.note: Fragment of a play based on the historical King Charles I, begun around 1819, and unpublished during the author's lifetime. See The Charles the First Draft Notebook, A Facsimile of Bodleian MS. Shelley adds. e. 17 for a recently-edited facsimile of the manuscript from Shelley's notebooks.

bibl.title: Shelley's Poetry and Prose

event.label: the Regency
event.note: The period between 1811 and 1820 when George, Prince of Wales, governed the kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland as Prince Regent during the illness and incapacity of his father, King George III. Parliament passed the Regency Act of 1811 on February 5, 1811 and the Regency ended with the death of King George III on January 29, 1820.

event.label: the Restoration
event.note: The period following the restoration of Stuart King Charles II to the English throne in 1660. On May 8, 1660, the Convention Parliament decreed that King Charles II had been the lawful monarch since January 30, 1649, the date his father, King Charles I had been executed. In legal and political terms, the Act invalidated all previous actions of the Commonwealth and the Protectorate. The term is sometimes also used to refer to the entire period between the restoration Charles II and the death of Queen Anne in 1714.
